Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that President Trump will sign an executive order creating term limits for Congress this week, which is not supported by any evidence.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence or official announcement from the White House or the Federal Register to confirm the existence of such an executive order.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that President Trump will take action on term limits for Congress based on his previous support for the idea, but no progress has been made on this front.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation is that the claim is based on a satire article that was narrated in a YouTube video, which further undermines its credibility.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there is no executive order on term limits listed in the Federal Register or any public indication from the White House about such an order.
Falters at times: The claim falters by relying on a YouTube video narrating a satire article, which undermines its credibility and accuracy.
